Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial Comparing Surgical Resection and Percutaneous Ethanol Injection for Small Hepatocellular Carcinoma

Trial_Design.evidence: Participants were randomly assigned to surgical resection or percutaneous ethanol injection groups.

Participants.evidence: 76 patients with one or two tumors â‰¤3 cm, hepatitis without cirrhosis, or Child class A or B cirrhosis without ascites or bleeding tendency were enrolled.

Intervention.evidence: Participants were randomly assigned to surgical resection or percutaneous ethanol injection groups.

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to compare disease recurrence and survival in patients with small hepatocellular carcinoma treated with surgical resection or percutaneous ethanol injection therapy.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was disease recurrence and survival, measured over a follow-up period of 12 to 59 months.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was conducted using a computer-generated sequence, and allocation was concealed.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 38 patients were randomised to each group.

Number_Analysed.evidence: In the percutaneous injection group, 18 patients experienced recurrence, and 3 died of cancer. In the surgical resection group, 15 patients had recurrence, and 5 died of cancer.

Result_Outcome.evidence: Cox regression and Kaplan-Meier analysis showed no significant difference in recurrence and survival between groups.

Harms.evidence: No significant adverse events were reported.

Trial_Registration.evidence: Trial registration and funding details were not provided.

Funding.evidence: Trial registration and funding details were not provided.
